title: High School Drivers
question_text:
In a large metropolitan area, the proportion of high school seniors who drive to school at least $3\text{ days a week}$ is $0.45$. A random sample of $25\text{ students}$ is chosen.
How would you calculate the probability that at least $13$ of these students drive to school at least $3\text{ days a week}$?

choices.text:
Use the multiplication rule for probabilities for the following item from the sample space, where $D$ = drives and $N$ = does not drive:
$DDDDDDDDDDDDDNNNNNNNNNNNN$
Calculate the binomial probability on a calculator using $\mu = 11.25$, $\sigma = 6.19$, and $X \ge 13$.
Use the normal approximation to the binomial because the sample size is large.
Use the binomial formula for $n = 25$, $X = 13$, and $p = 0.45$.
Use the normal approximation to the binomial because $np \ge 10$ and $n(1-p) \ge 10$.

solution:
One can use the normal approximation to the binomial when $np \ge 10$ and $n(1-p) \ge 10$. In this problem:

$$np = (25)(0.45) = 11.25$$

...and:

n(1−p)=(25)(0.55)=13.75

...so the conditions for using the normal approximation are met.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; there are many lines from the sample space that would be required in order to calculate the entire probability, not just the one line listed here.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; it states the wrong standard deviation; it should be
√
(25)(0.45)(0.55)
≈2.49.

Additionally, the calculator requires that you input the values of n
and p
, not μ
and σ
.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; a large sample size in and of itself does not automatically allow the use of the normal approximation.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; binomial formula would have to be used 13 times, for each of the values of interest for X
(13≤X≤25
), to calculate the desired probability.
